remixlab.proscene

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.fpstiming.AnimatorObject
      • remixlab.dandelion.core.AbstractScene
        • remixlab.proscene.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PConstants, Grabber, Constants, Animator

    public class Scene
extends AbstractScene
implements PConstants
    A 2D or 3D interactive Processing Scene. The Scene is a specialization of the AbstractScene, providing an interface between Dandelion and Processing.

    Usage

    To use a Scene you have three choices:
    1. Direct instantiation. In this case you should instantiate your own Scene object at the PApplet.setup() function. See the example BasicUse.
    2. Inheritance. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement AbstractScene.proscenium() which defines the objects in your scene. Just make sure to define the PApplet.draw() method, even if it's empty. See the example AlternativeUse.
    3. External draw handler registration. In addition (not being part of Dandelion), you can even declare an external drawing method and then register it at the Scene with addDrawHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. This strategy may be useful when there are multiple viewers sharing the same drawing code. See the example StandardCamera.

    Interactivity mechanisms

    ProScene provides powerful interactivity mechanisms allowing a wide range of scene setups ranging from very simple to complex ones. For convenience, two interaction mechanisms are provided by default: AbstractScene.keyboardAgent(), and AbstractScene.motionAgent() (which in the desktop version of proscene defaults to a mouseAgent()):
    1. The default keyboard agent provides shortcuts to Dandelion keyboard actions such as AbstractScene.drawGrid() or AbstractScene.drawAxes(). See setKeyboardShortcut(Character, remixlab.dandelion.core.Constants.KeyboardAction) and setKeyboardShortcut(int, int, remixlab.dandelion.core.Constants.KeyboardAction).
    2. The default mouse agent provides high-level methods to manage Eye and Frame motion actions. Please refer to the different setMouseButtonBinding(), setMouseClickBinding(), setMouseWheelBinding() methods.

    Animation mechanisms

    ProScene provides three animation mechanisms to define how your scene evolves over time:
    1. Overriding the Dandelion AnimatorObject.animate() method. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement AnimatorObject.animate() which defines how your scene objects evolve over time. See the example Animation.
    2. By checking if the Dandelion AbstractScene's AnimatorObject.timer() was triggered within the frame. See the example Flock.
    3. External animation handler registration. In addition (not being part of Dandelion), you can also declare an external animation method and then register it at the Scene with addAnimationHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. See the example AnimationHandler.

      void setDefaultKeyboardShortcuts()
      Restores the default keyboard shortcuts: 'a' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_AXES_VISUAL_HINT
      'f' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_FRAME_VISUAL_HINT
      'g' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_GRID_VISUAL_HINT
      'm' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_ANIMATION
      'e' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_CAMERA_TYPE
      'h' -> KeyboardAction.DISPLAY_INFO
      'r' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_PATHS_VISUAL_HINT
      's' -> KeyboardAction.INTERPOLATE_TO_FIT
      'S' -> KeyboardAction.SHOW_ALL
      left_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_LEFT
      right_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_RIGHT
      up_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_UP
      down_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_DOWN
      'CTRL' + '1' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_1
      'ALT' + '1' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_1
      '1' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_1
      'CTRL' + '2' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_2
      'ALT' + '2' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_2
      '2' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_2
      'CTRL' + '3' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_3
      'ALT' + '3' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_3
      '3' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_3
      void setKeyboardShortcut(Character key, Constants.KeyboardAction action)
      Binds the key shortcut to the (Keyboard) dandelion action.
      void setKeyboardShortcut(int mask, int vKey, Constants.KeyboardAction action)

      void setKeyCodeToPlayPath(int code, int path)
      Set the virtual-key to play path.
      void setMouseAsArcball()
      Set mouse bindings as 'arcball': 1.
      void setMouseAsFirstPerson()
      Set mouse bindings as 'first-person': 1.
      void setMouseAsThirdPerson()
      Set mouse bindings as third-person: Left button -> MOVE_FORWARD
      Center button -> LOOK_AROUND
      Right button -> MOVE_BACKWARD
      Shift + Left button -> ROLL
      Shift + Center button -> DRIVE
      Also set the following (common) bindings are: 2 left clicks -> ALIGN_FRAME
      2right clicks -> CENTER_FRAME
      Wheel in 2D -> SCALE both, InteractiveFrame and InteractiveEyeFrame
      Wheel in 3D -> SCALE InteractiveFrame, and ZOOM InteractiveEyeFrame
      void setMouseButtonBinding(Constants.Target target, int button, Constants.DOF2Action action)

      • Scene

        public Scene(PApplet p,
     PGraphics pg,
     int x,
     int y)
        Main constructor defining a left-handed Processing compatible Scene. Calls AbstractScene.setMatrixHelper(MatrixHelper) using a customized MatrixHelper depending on the pg type (see Scene.P5Java2DMatrixHelper and Scene.P5GLMatrixHelper). The constructor instantiates the AbstractScene.inputHandler() and the AnimatorObject.timingHandler(), sets the AXIS and GRID visual hint flags, instantiates the AbstractScene.eye() (a Camera if the Scene is3D() or a Window if the Scene AbstractScene.is2D()). It also instantiates the AbstractScene.keyboardAgent() and the mouseAgent(), and finally calls AbstractScene.init().

        An off-screen Processing Scene is defined if pg != p.g. In this case the x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen Scene is expected to be displayed, e.g., for instance with a call to Processing the image(img, x, y) function. If pg == p.g) (which defines an on-screen Scene, see also AbstractScene.isOffscreen()), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values).

        See Also:
        AbstractScene.AbstractScene(), Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphics)

      • setMouseAsArcball

        public void setMouseAsArcball()
        Set mouse bindings as 'arcball':

        1. InteractiveFrame bindings
        Left button -> ROTATE
        Center button -> SCALE
        Right button -> TRANSLATE
        Shift + Center button -> SCREEN_TRANSLATE
        Shift + Right button -> SCREEN_ROTATE

        2. InteractiveEyeFrame bindings
        Left button -> ROTATE
        Center button -> ZOOM
        Right button -> TRANSLATE
        Shift + Left button -> ZOOM_ON_REGION
        Shift + Center button -> SCREEN_TRANSLATE
        Shift + Right button -> SCREEN_ROTATE.

        Also set the following (common) bindings are:

        2 left clicks -> ALIGN_FRAME
        2right clicks -> CENTER_FRAME
        Wheel in 2D -> SCALE both, InteractiveFrame and InteractiveEyeFrame
        Wheel in 3D -> SCALE InteractiveFrame, and ZOOM InteractiveEyeFrame

        See Also:
        setMouseAsFirstPerson(), setMouseAsThirdPerson()

      • setMouseAsFirstPerson

        public void setMouseAsFirstPerson()
        Set mouse bindings as 'first-person':

        1. InteractiveFrame bindings
        Left button -> ROTATE
        Center button -> SCALE
        Right button -> TRANSLATE
        Shift + Center button -> SCREEN_TRANSLATE
        Shift + Right button -> SCREEN_ROTATE

        2. InteractiveEyeFrame bindings
        Left button -> MOVE_FORWARD
        Center button -> LOOK_AROUND
        Right button -> MOVE_BACKWARD
        Shift + Left button -> ROLL
        Shift + Center button -> DRIVE
        Ctrl + Wheel -> ROLL
        Shift + Wheel -> DRIVE

        Also set the following (common) bindings are:

        2 left clicks -> ALIGN_FRAME
        2right clicks -> CENTER_FRAME
        Wheel in 2D -> SCALE both, InteractiveFrame and InteractiveEyeFrame
        Wheel in 3D -> SCALE InteractiveFrame, and ZOOM InteractiveEyeFrame

        See Also:
        setMouseAsArcball(), setMouseAsThirdPerson()

      • setMouseAsThirdPerson

        public void setMouseAsThirdPerson()
        Set mouse bindings as third-person:

        Left button -> MOVE_FORWARD
        Center button -> LOOK_AROUND
        Right button -> MOVE_BACKWARD
        Shift + Left button -> ROLL
        Shift + Center button -> DRIVE

        Also set the following (common) bindings are:

        2 left clicks -> ALIGN_FRAME
        2right clicks -> CENTER_FRAME
        Wheel in 2D -> SCALE both, InteractiveFrame and InteractiveEyeFrame
        Wheel in 3D -> SCALE InteractiveFrame, and ZOOM InteractiveEyeFrame

        See Also:
        setMouseAsArcball(), setMouseAsFirstPerson()

      • setDefaultKeyboardShortcuts

        public void setDefaultKeyboardShortcuts()
        Restores the default keyboard shortcuts:

        'a' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_AXES_VISUAL_HINT
        'f' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_FRAME_VISUAL_HINT
        'g' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_GRID_VISUAL_HINT
        'm' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_ANIMATION
        'e' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_CAMERA_TYPE
        'h' -> KeyboardAction.DISPLAY_INFO
        'r' -> KeyboardAction.TOGGLE_PATHS_VISUAL_HINT
        's' -> KeyboardAction.INTERPOLATE_TO_FIT
        'S' -> KeyboardAction.SHOW_ALL
        left_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_LEFT
        right_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_RIGHT
        up_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_UP
        down_arrow -> KeyboardAction.MOVE_DOWN
        'CTRL' + '1' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_1
        'ALT' + '1' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_1
        '1' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_1
        'CTRL' + '2' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_2
        'ALT' + '2' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_2
        '2' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_2
        'CTRL' + '3' -> KeyboardAction.ADD_KEYFRAME_TO_PATH_3
        'ALT' + '3' -> KeyboardAction.DELETE_PATH_3
        '3' -> KeyboardAction.PLAY_PATH_3

        See Also:
        KeyboardAgent.setDefaultShortcuts(), setMouseAsArcball(), setMouseAsFirstPerson(), setMouseAsThirdPerson()

      • setKeyCodeToPlayPath

        public void setKeyCodeToPlayPath(int code,
                        int path)
        Set the virtual-key to play path. Defaults are java.awt.event.KeyEvent.VK_1, java.awt.event.KeyEvent.VK_2 and java.awt.event.KeyEvent.VK_3 which will play paths 1, 2, 3, resp.

        disableKeyboardAgent in class AbstractScene
        See Also:

      • mouseAgent

        public Scene.ProsceneMouse mouseAgent()
        Returns the default mouse agent handling Processing mouse events. Simply returns a ProsceneMouse cast of the AbstractScene.motionAgent().

        The use of AbstractScene.motionAgent() is preferable and encouraged since it's more general and platform independent, i.e., it returns a "mouse agent" for the proscene desktop version or a "touch agent" for the android version.

        If you plan to customize your mouse you can either use this method or one of the multiple high-level methods provided (recommended and simpler way), such as setMouseAsArcball, setMouseAsFirstPerson(), setMouseAsThirdPerson(), setMouseButtonBinding, setMouseClickBinding, setMouseWheelBinding, etc. All those methods actually wrap the mouse agent to achieve their functionality.

        See Also:
        AbstractScene.keyboardAgent()

      • isMouseAgentEnabled

        @Deprecated
public boolean isMouseAgentEnabled()
        Deprecated. 
        Use AbstractScene.isMotionAgentEnabled() instead.

      • enableMotionAgent

        Overrides:

        Sets all AnimatorObject.timingHandler() timers as (single-threaded) SeqTimer(s).
        See Also:

        public void setNonSeqTimers()

        See Also:
        setSeqTimers(), switchTimers(), areTimersSeq()

      • areTimersSeq

        public boolean areTimersSeq()
        Returns:
        true, if timing is handling sequentially (i.e., all AnimatorObject.timingHandler() timers are (single-threaded) SeqTimer(s)).
        See Also:
        setSeqTimers(), setNonSeqTimers(), switchTimers()

      • switchTimers

        public void switchTimers()
        If areTimersSeq() calls setNonSeqTimers(), otherwise call setSeqTimers().

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.preDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If AbstractScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), AbstractScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.postDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

        If AbstractScene.isOffscreen() does nothing.

        See Also:
        pre(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), AbstractScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • beginDraw

        public void beginDraw()
        Only if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just after the pg() beginDraw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.preDraw().

        If pg() is resized then (re)sets the scene width() and height(), and calls Eye.setScreenWidthAndHeight(int, int).

        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), AbstractScene.postDraw(), pre(), endDraw(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • endDraw

        public void endDraw()
        Only if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen(). This method should be called just before pg() endDraw() method. Simply calls AbstractScene.postDraw().
        See Also:
        draw(), AbstractScene.preDraw(), AbstractScene.postDraw(), beginDraw(), pre(), AbstractScene.isOffscreen()

      • pg

        public PGraphics pg()
        Returns the PGraphics instance this Scene is related to. It may be the PApplets one, if the Scene is on-screen or an user-defined if the Scene AbstractScene.isOffscreen().

      • addDrawHandler

        public void addDrawHandler(Object obj,
                  String methodName)
        Attempt to add a 'draw' handler method to the Scene. The default event handler is a method that returns void and has one single Scene parameter.
        Parameters:
        obj - the object to handle the event
        methodName - the method to execute in the object handler class
        See Also:
        removeDrawHandler(), invokeDrawHandler()

      • removeDrawHandler

        public void removeDrawHandler()
        Unregisters the 'draw' handler method (if any has previously been added to the Scene).
        See Also:
        addDrawHandler(Object, String), invokeDrawHandler()

      • hasDrawHandler

        public boolean hasDrawHandler()
        Returns true if the user has registered a 'draw' handler method to the Scene and false otherwise.
        See Also:
        addDrawHandler(Object, String), invokeDrawHandler()

      • pixelDepth

        public float pixelDepth(Point pixel)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Returns the depth (z-value) of the object under the pixel.

        The z-value ranges in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D Note that this value is not a linear interpolation between Camera.zNear() and Camera.zFar(); z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z'); where z' is the distance from the point you project to the camera, along the Camera.viewDirection(). See the gluUnProject man page for details.

        Specified by:
        pixelDepth in class AbstractScene

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(Eye eye,
           float scale)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws a representation of the camera in the 3D virtual world.

        The near and far planes are drawn as quads, the frustum is drawn using lines and the camera up vector is represented by an arrow to disambiguate the drawing.

        When drawFarPlane is false, only the near plane is drawn. scale can be used to scale the drawing: a value of 1.0 (default) will draw the Camera's frustum at its actual size.

        Note: The drawing of a Scene's own Scene.camera() should not be visible, but may create artifacts due to numerical imprecisions.

        Specified by:
        drawEye in class AbstractScene

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(KeyFrameInterpolator kfi,
            int mask,
            int nbFrames,
            float scale)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws the path used to interpolate the KeyFrameInterpolator.frame()

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), a camera representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), oriented axes are regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and cameras
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axes

        In the case where camera or axes are drawn, nbFrames controls the number of objects (axes or camera) drawn between two successive keyFrames. When nbFrames = 1, only the path KeyFrames are drawn. nbFrames = 2 also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30. nbFrames should divide 30 so that an object is drawn for each KeyFrame. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the camera and axes drawing. A value of AbstractScene.radius() should give good results.

        Specified by:
        drawPath in class AbstractScene

      • drawPickingTargets

        public void drawPickingTargets(boolean keyFrame)
        Description copied from class: AbstractScene
        Draws all InteractiveFrames' picking targets: a shooter target visual hint of InteractiveFrame.grabsInputThreshold() pixels size. Attention: the target is drawn either if the iFrame is part of camera path and keyFrame is true, or if the iFrame is not part of camera path and keyFrame is false.
